div.head: Tour of 1828
div.p: The Ruskins planned a “great tour” of the Lake District in 1828, intended to compensate for the previous, leaner years of travel, the Tours of 1826-27, which were confined mainly to visiting family in Perth, Scotland. To plan the tour, and then to record its progress, Ruskin devoted MS IVB (in its initial use) to Travel Itinerary and Tour Notes, 1828, which consists of itineraries and notes for this trip. The planned tour of the Lakes not fulfilled until 1830, however, since the 1828 journey was interrupted on 24 May by news of the 18 May death of Janet Richardson (“Aunt Jessie”), John Jamesʼs sister, the widow of Patrick Richardson (1774-1824) of Perth (Burd, introduction to Dearden, ed., Tour to the Lakes in Cumberland, 7; Viljoen, Ruskin's Scottish Heritage, 185; Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, xlviii-xlix; Ruskin, Works, 35:70-71).

The Ruskins did not terminate their journey immediately, although they did not carry through with their visit to the Lakes. On 3 June 1828, they were at Stratford-on-Avon, where John and his father signed the Visitor's Book at Shakespeare's Birthplace (Dearden, ed., Tour of the Lakes in Cumberland, 64 n. 14). In John James's accounts for 1828, entries for the two months May and June are omitted from most lists of expenses, while in the expenses for "Travelling" John James entered a total amount of £332 for "Journey", dated 17 July--close to the date when John James informed Gray that they would return to Herne Hill, expecting to receive Mary. (Notably missing entries for May and June is the list of "House Expenses", although for June "Servants Wages" are covered, as well as "Mrs Rs Cloaths" [sic], which lists an expense for "Harmans"--i.e., the London milliner, Harman & Broadbent, where Margaret frequently purchased her clothing. Perhaps an order was sent for mourning dress? See John James Ruskin, Account Book [1827-45], 8v, 6v, 7v, 7r; and for Harman & Broadbent, see Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 1:410 n. 6).
